medical_necessity.title: Medical Necessity Criteria
medical_necessity.content:
MRI of the lumbar spine is considered medically necessary when ANY of the following criteria are met:

1. Conservative treatment failure for at least 6 weeks including:
   - Physical therapy (minimum 6 sessions)
   - NSAIDs or muscle relaxants
   - Activity modification

2. Documented neurological deficits including:
   - Motor weakness in specific myotomal distribution
   - Sensory changes in dermatomal pattern
   - Reflex changes (diminished or absent)
   - Positive straight leg raise test

3. Red flag symptoms present:
   - Cauda equina syndrome (bowel/bladder dysfunction)
   - Progressive neurological deficit
   - Suspected malignancy (unexplained weight loss, history of cancer)
   - Suspected infection (fever, IV drug use)
   - Suspected fracture (trauma, osteoporosis)

4. Pre-surgical planning when surgery is indicated based on clinical findings

documentation_requirements.title: Required Documentation
documentation_requirements.content:
The following documentation must be submitted with the PA request:

1. Clinical notes documenting:
   - Duration and nature of symptoms
   - Response to conservative treatment

2. Physical therapy records (if applicable):
   - Number of sessions completed
   - Treatment provided
   - Outcome/response to treatment

3. Previous imaging results (if available):
   - X-ray reports
   - Prior MRI/CT reports

4. Medication history:
   - List of medications tried
   - Duration of each medication trial
   - Response/side effects

exclusions.title: Exclusions and Limitations
exclusions.content:
MRI lumbar spine will NOT be approved in the following circumstances:

1. Routine screening without clinical indication
2. Non-specific low back pain < 6 weeks duration without red flags
3. Duplicate imaging within 12 months without documented clinical change
4. Patient has not attempted conservative management
5. Request for surveillance imaging without new symptoms

repeat_imaging.title: Repeat Imaging Criteria
repeat_imaging.content:
Repeat MRI within 12 months of prior study requires documentation of:

1. New or significantly worsening neurological deficits
2. New red flag symptoms
3. Post-surgical evaluation
4. New trauma
5. Significant clinical change not explained by prior imaging
6. Pre-operative planning for scheduled surgery

covered_indications.title: Covered Indications
covered_indications.content:
TNF inhibitor therapy is covered for the following FDA-approved indications:

1. Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
2. Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA)
3. Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS)
4. Crohn's Disease
5. Ulcerative Colitis
6. Plaque Psoriasis (moderate to severe)
7. Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis

step_therapy.title: Step Therapy Requirements
step_therapy.content:
Prior to approval of TNF inhibitor therapy, the following step therapy requirements must be met:

For Rheumatoid Arthritis:
1. Trial and failure of methotrexate for minimum 3 months at adequate dose (15-25mg/week)
   OR documented contraindication/intolerance to methotrexate
2. Documented moderate to severe disease activity (DAS28 > 3.2)

For Psoriatic Arthritis:
1. Trial and failure of at least one conventional DMARD (methotrexate, sulfasalazine, or leflunomide)
   for minimum 3 months
   OR documented contraindication/intolerance

For Inflammatory Bowel Disease:
1. Trial and failure of conventional therapy (corticosteroids, aminosalicylates, immunomodulators)
   OR documented contraindication/intolerance

documentation_requirements.title: Required Documentation
documentation_requirements.content:
The following documentation must be submitted:

1. Confirmed diagnosis with supporting documentation
2. Disease activity assessment:
   - For RA: DAS28 score, swollen/tender joint counts
   - For IBD: Disease activity index, endoscopy reports
   - For Psoriasis: PASI score, BSA involvement

3. Step therapy documentation:
   - Medication name, dose, duration
   - Reason for discontinuation (failure, intolerance, contraindication)
   - Dates of treatment

4. Laboratory results:
   - For RA: RF, Anti-CCP, CRP, ESR
   - CBC, CMP, LFTs

5. Screening tests:
   - TB screening (QuantiFERON or PPD)
   - Hepatitis B and C screening

6. Provider attestation form

failure_criteria.title: Definition of Treatment Failure
failure_criteria.content:
Treatment failure is defined as:

1. Inadequate response: Persistent moderate to severe disease activity despite adequate trial
2. Intolerance: Documented adverse effects requiring discontinuation
3. Contraindication: Medical condition precluding use of medication

Adequate trial is defined as:
- Minimum 3 months of therapy
- At therapeutic dose
- With documented compliance
